commit_message:
Enhancement of volume creation from source vol

This feature is to allow creating volume from source vol
in diffeent volume hosts or with different encryptions.

APIImpact

Change-Id: I1ad63b8cf63a9fd32bf25b87be7bb0968944b853
Implements: blueprint create-volume-from-source-enhancement
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/47/314847/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ============================================= Create volume from source vol in different storages ============================================= https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/create-volume-from-source-enhancement Enable creating volume from source vol in different storages or with different encryptions. Problem description =================== Currently it only allows to create volume from source vol in same storage. Use Cases ========= * Customers creates a volume in a storage device from another volume which is in another storage device. * Customers creates a volume from another volume but both volumes have different encryptions. Proposed change =============== Above user cases it needs data migration. When creating from source vol with specified volume type, it checks whether new volume is created in same volume host with same encryptions. If yes, nothing needs to chanage. If no, it needs data migration. Use following steps to create the new volume. * Create a temporary cloned volume from source vol. * RPC call to create destination volume with specified volume type. * Set temp_volume_id in the new volume. * Map both volume to volume host. If any volume is encrypted, it needs to attach encryptors. * Data migration. * Delete temporary cloned volume and unset temp_volume_id. If error happens in above steps, the temporary cloned volume is deleted the field temp_volume_id is unset, and status of new volume is set to error. Meanwhile, it needs resource cleanup during volume host starts, except set creating volumes to error, it needs to check temp_volume_id field, and cleans temporary volumes if exist. Alternatives ------------ Create new volume in same storage and retype. It needs user to do it in two steps. Data model impact ----------------- Add a new field called temp_volume_id in table volumes. REST API impact --------------- Change the existing create API to take a new parameter called allow_data_migration. Only when this parameter is specified as True, it allows above enhanced operations. * Create volume * /v3/{tenant_id}/volumes * Method: POST * JSON schema definition for V3:: { "volume": { "size": "XXX", # existing "volume_type": "XXX", # existing "source_volid": "XXX", # existing "allow_data_migration": "True", #new } } Security impact --------------- If source volume and new volume have different encryptions, Cinder needs to access encryption keys and decrypt the data. Notifications impact -------------------- None. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Performance Impact ------------------ It needs data migration and as a result more time to wait for new volume available. Other deployer impact --------------------- None. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: LisaLi <xiaoyan.li@intel.com> Work Items ---------- * Add new field temp_volume_id to volumes. * Add the steps to create volume from source vol in different storages. * Add encryptors attachment. [1] is needed. Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Both unit and Tempest tests need to be created to cover the code change that mentioned in "Proposed change". Documentation Impact ==================== The cinder API documentation will need to be updated to describe the change. References ========== * [1]: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/247372/

commit_message:
Properly inject network_data.json in configdrive

The file "network_data.json" is not currently found in the folder
"openstack/2015-10-15/" of config drive, only in "openstack/latest/".
The patch makes sure its found in both folders.

Closes-bug: #1513267
Change-Id: Ifcd4fadb91fcd360af5cf0988178992f2905190a
(cherry picked from commit edea873565d07120141ae0f76199d6a3aee2959d)

commit_message:
Fix bugs on booting a server from volume like "Change #312845"

The arg of image must be None,when booting server from volume.
Otherwise still boot server from image.
Related function: boot_server_from_volume_and_delete, boot_server_from_volume_and_resize,
boot_server_from_volume_and_live_migrate.

Change-Id: I4338e08a7b3de9bde89265d7f4c342aaec6ab565

commit_message:
Changed an HTTP exception to return proper code

POSTing to /servers with a content-type of text/plain
and a text/plain body results in a response code of 400.
It should be 415. I found this line in the code that
appears to handle this singular case and modified
the HTTP exception used to the correct one. Tests were
also updated accordingly.

Conflicts:
        nova/api/openstack/wsgi.py
        nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/legacy_v2/test_servers.py

Change-Id: I5fa1fdba56803b2ef63b1efaaeeced6ceb7779d9
Closes-Bug: 1567977
(cherry picked from commit a7019a87ba696509d825c6c6f2220331e4ffb033)

subject: Fix pool_full race condition
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-13 02:16:29.000000000', 'files': ['ldappool/tests/test_ldappool.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/ldappool/commit/b08b776fdc0e2138065a02979c93c39a16bbc103', 'message': 'Fix pool_full race condition

Sometimes the main thread starts before the spawned thread, which means
that the thread that is supposed to hold open a connection starts after
the main thread has already successfully made a connection. This means
that the test for a successful connection attempt[1] was nearly useless
since the main thread would get the connection first and activate it[2]
no matter how long the spawned thread waited, and the test for a failed
connection attempt[3] would intermittently fail since is sometimes able
to get the connection before the busy-waiting worker thread does.
Adding a short sleep in the main thread ensures that the main thread
yields to the worker thread and it can grab the connection first so we
can actually test what happens in the main thread.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/ldappool/tree/ldappool/tests/test_ldappool.py#n183
[2] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/ldappool/tree/ldappool/__init__.py#n167
[3] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/ldappool/tree/ldappool/tests/test_ldappool.py#n193

Change-Id: Ic32ef931cd672907dd14d5ec6339a6d7d9a2018d
'}]
commit_message:
Fix pool_full race condition

Sometimes the main thread starts before the spawned thread, which means
that the thread that is supposed to hold open a connection starts after
the main thread has already successfully made a connection. This means
that the test for a successful connection attempt[1] was nearly useless
since the main thread would get the connection first and activate it[2]
no matter how long the spawned thread waited, and the test for a failed
connection attempt[3] would intermittently fail since is sometimes able
to get the connection before the busy-waiting worker thread does.
Adding a short sleep in the main thread ensures that the main thread
yields to the worker thread and it can grab the connection first so we
can actually test what happens in the main thread.

[1] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/ldappool/tree/ldappool/tests/test_ldappool.py#n183
[2] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/ldappool/tree/ldappool/__init__.py#n167
[3] http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/ldappool/tree/ldappool/tests/test_ldappool.py#n193

Change-Id: Ic32ef931cd672907dd14d5ec6339a6d7d9a2018d

commit_message:
Fix bug expirer unexpectedly deletes object created after x-delete-at

As reported at bug/1546067, expirer might accidentally deletes an object
which is created after x-delete-at timestamp. This is because expirer
sends a request with "X-Timestamp: <current_timestamp>" and tombstone
is named as <requested_x_timestamp>.ts so if object creation time is
between x-delete-at and expirer's DELETE request x-timestamp, the object
might be hidden by tombstone.

This possibility can be simply removed if the value of x-timestamp which
an expirer sends is the same timestamp as x-delete-at of an actual object.
Namely, expirer pretends to delete an object at the time an user really
wants to delete it.

Change-Id: I53e343f4e73b0b1c4ced9a3bc054541473d26cf8
Closes-Bug: #1546067

added_lines: My bay-create fails with error: "Failed to create trustee XXX in domain XXX" Check the `trustee for bay`_ Trustee for bay --------------- When a user creates a bay, Magnum will dynamically create a bay user. Then, Magnum will create a trust relationship between bay creator (the "trustor") and the bay user (the "trustee"). In runtime, the bay will use the bay user to access OpenStack services (i.e. Neutron, Swift, etc.). For details, please refer <http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/magnum/tree/specs/create-trustee-user-for-each-bay.rst>`_. If Magnum fails to create the trustee, check the magnum config file (usually in /etc/magnum/magnum.conf). Make sure the 'trust' and 'auth_uri' is set and their values are correct: [keystone_authtoken] auth_uri = http://controller:5000/v3 ... [trust] trustee_domain_admin_password = XXX trustee_domain_admin_id = XXX trustee_domain_id = XXX If the 'trust' group is missing, you need to perform the following steps to create the domain and domain admin: .. code-block:: bash source /opt/stack/devstack/accrc/admin/admin export OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION=3 unset OS_AUTH_TYPE openstack domain create magnum openstack user create trustee_domain_admin --password=secret \ --domain=magnum openstack role add --user=trustee_domain_admin --domain=magnum admin source /opt/stack/devstack/functions export MAGNUM_CONF=/etc/magnum/magnum.conf iniset $MAGNUM_CONF trust trustee_domain_id \ $(openstack domain show magnum | awk '/ id /{print $4}') iniset $MAGNUM_CONF trust trustee_domain_admin_id \ $(openstack user show trustee_domain_admin | awk '/ id /{print $4}') iniset $MAGNUM_CONF trust trustee_domain_admin_password secret Then, restart magnum-api and magnum-cond to pick up the new configuration. For your reference, Magnum creates the trustee by using the snippet below. You might use it for troubleshooting if you want. .. code-block:: python from keystoneauth1.identity import v3 as ka_v3 from keystoneauth1 import session as ka_session from keystoneclient.v3 import client as kc_v3 auth = ka_v3.Password( auth_url=self.auth_url, user_id=CONF.trust.trustee_domain_admin_id, domain_id=CONF.trust.trustee_domain_id, password=CONF.trust.trustee_domain_admin_password) ) session = ka_session.Session(auth=auth) domain_admin_client = kc_v3.Client(session=session) user = domain_admin_client.users.create( name=username, password=password)

commit_message:
DOCS: Host deployment section - cleanup

As per discussion in the OSA docs summit session, clean up
of installation guide. This fixes typos, minor RST mark up
changes, and passive voice.

Change-Id: I669bfdaf3483e62602361d53c91f801556956684
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/58/315458/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~`Home <index.html>`_ OpenStack-Ansible Installation Guide Chapter 2. Deployment host -------------------------- **Figure 2.1. Installation work flow** .. image:: figures/workflow-deploymenthost.png The OSA installation process recommends one deployment host. The deployment host contains Ansible and orchestrates the OSA installation on the target hosts. One of the target hosts, preferably one of the infrastructure variants, can be used as the deployment host. To use a deployment host as a target host, follow the steps in `Chapter 3, *Target hosts* <targethosts.html>`_ on the deployment host. This guide assumes separate deployment and target hosts. Installing the operating system~~~~~~ Install the `Ubuntu Server 14.04 (Trusty Tahr) LTS 64-bit <http://releases.ubuntu.com/14.04/>`_ operating system on the deployment host with at least one network interface configured to access the Internet or suitable local repositories. Configuring the operating system ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Install additional software packages and configure NTP. #. Install additional software packages if not already installed during operating system installation: .. code-block:: shell-session # apt-get install aptitude build-essential git ntp ntpdate \ openssh-server python-dev sudo #. Configure NTP to synchronize with a suitable time source. Configuring the network ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Ansible deployments will fail if the deployment server is unable to ssh to the containers. Configure the deployment host to be on the same network designated for container management. This configuration reduces the rate of failure due to connectivity issues. The following network information is used as an example: Container management: 172.29.236.0/22 (VLAN 10) Select an IP from this range to assign to the deployment host. Installing source and dependencies ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Install the source and dependencies for the deployment host. #. Clone the OSA repository into the ``/opt/openstack-ansible`` directory: .. code-block:: shell-session # git clone -b TAG https://github.com/openstack/openstack-ansible.git /opt/openstack-ansible Replace *``TAG``* with the current stable release tag. #. Change to the ``/opt/openstack-ansible`` directory, and run the Ansible bootstrap script: .. code-block:: shell-session # scripts/bootstrap-ansible.sh Configuring Secure Shell (SSH) keys ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Ansible uses Secure Shell (SSH) with public key authentication for connectivity between the deployment and target hosts. To reduce user interaction during Ansible operations, key pairs should not include pass phrases. However, if a pass phrase is required, consider using the **ssh-agent** and **ssh-add** commands to temporarily store the pass phrase before performing Ansible operations. -------------- .. include:: navigation.txt

commit_message:
Support alias for heat template version names

Currently, the heat template version is named by date. It is not easy for
users or developers to remember. So add an alias support for the template
version names.

Change-Id: I37fbca824d43c0203343d89536d4bd8cbfb3d1bf
Blueprint: support-alias-for-heat-template-version-names
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat-specs refs/changes/91/293891/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode .. This template should be in ReSTructured text. The filename in the git repository should match the launchpad URL, for example a URL of https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/awesome-thing should be named awesome-thing.rst . Please do not delete any of the sections in this template. If you have nothing to say for a whole section, just write: None For help with syntax, see http://sphinx-doc.org/rest.html To test out your formatting, see http://www.tele3.cz/jbar/rest/rest.html ============================================= Support Alias for Heat Template Version Names ============================================= Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/heat/+spec/support-alias-for-heat-template-version-names Currently, the heat template version is named by date. It is not easy for users or developers to remember. So add a alias support for the template version names. Problem description =================== It is not easy to remember the template version name as it contains a specified date. Proposed change =============== In order to support alias for heat template version names, we can use heat environment to implement it. We need to add a section named "TEMPLATE_VERSION_REGISTRY" in environment format. We can write the environment file and template file as follows: #cat environment.yaml template_version_registry: my_version: 2016-04-08 #cat template.yaml heat_template_version: my_version And then create the stack: # heat stack-create test_stack1 --template-file=./template.yaml --environment-file=./environment.yaml Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: Di XiaoLi <dixiaobj@cn.ibm.com> Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: newton-1 Work Items ---------- * Add alias support for heat template version names. * Add example templates. * Update the documentation. Dependencies ============ None

commit_message:
Ironic: update context in looping call

The _wait_for_active looping call refreshes the instance, but doesn't
update the context for the green thread it runs in before doing so. If
we wind up doing any lazy loads, this will explode.

Update the context to keep things from breaking in the future.

Change-Id: Ibb6a355e2c326b04902027dc57634b1f1401a7b4
Related-Bug: #1580987

commit_message:
Install proliantutils in IPA's virtualenv

The proliant-tools element helps to do RAID
configuration in ironic for HPE servers.
This fix proposes to install the proliantutils
in ironic-python-agent's virtualenv created
using ironic-agent element.

Closes-Bug: 1563648
Change-Id: If63c725a42740ab244a2b4004797cba09d0f154e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/16/299116/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: IPADIR=/usr/share/ironic-python-agent $IPADIR/venv/bin/pip install proliantutils

commit_message:
[admin-guide] Add NUMA topology documentation

Document the 'hw:numa_nodes', 'hw:numa_cpus.N' and 'hw:numa_mem.N'
options.

Change-Id: I3728fd447f82094d1ad1e065bd4fef36e72dbdb5
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/38/313538/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: NUMA topology For the libvirt driver, you can define the host NUMA placement for the guest vCPU threads. For flavors whose RAM and vCPU allocations are larger than the size of NUMA nodes in the compute hosts, defining NUMA topology enables hosts to better utilize NUMA and improve performance of the guest OS. .. code-block:: console $ openstack flavor set FLAVOR-NAME \ --property hw:numa_nodes=FLAVOR-NODES \ --property hw:numa_cpus.N=FLAVOR-CORES \ --property hw:numa_mem.N=FLAVOR-MEMORY Where: - FLAVOR-NODES: (integer) The number of host NUMA nodes to restrict the guest vCPU threads to. If unspecified, then the vCPU threads can run on any number of the NUMA nodes available. - N: (integer) The NUMA node to apply a given CPU/memory configuration to. - FLAVOR-CORES: (comma-separated list of integers) A list of vCPUs to map to NUMA node N. If not specified, vCPUs will be evenly divided among available NUMA nodes. - FLAVOR-MEMORY: (integer) The number of GB of memory to map to NUMA node N. If not specified, memory will evenly divided among available NUMA nodes. .. note:: ``hw:numa_cpus.N`` and ``hw:numa_mem.N`` are only valid if ``hw:numa_nodes`` is set. Additionally, they are only required if the instance's NUMA nodes have an asymetrical allocation of CPUs and RAM (important for some NFV workloads). .. note:: If the combined values of ``hw:numa_cpus.N`` or ``hw:numa_mem.N`` are the greater than the available number of CPUs/memory, an exception is raised.

commit_message:
DNM: testing ceph gate fix

Depends on the tempest change that reverts the skip on the busted
test, and that tempest change depends on the nova fix.

We have to test this outside of Tempest because the ceph job doesn't
currently run on Tempest changes.

Change-Id: If928d18aba583f050650945e9323ac43df3b14bb
Depends-On: I086e59cc49cd5ab2edeae852add3211bec79d30b

subject: Fix TestNeutronv2.test_deallocate_for_instance_2* race failures
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-10 16:32:21.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/network/test_neutronv2.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/3d3fb49cd1589d726925b758e8eaaa2f8a1b22d0', 'message': 'Fix TestNeutronv2.test_deallocate_for_instance_2* race failures

The unit tests
    test_deallocate_for_instance_2_with_requested
    test_deallocate_for_instance_2
in
    nova.tests.unit.network.test_neutronv2.TestNeutronv2
fail randomly. An example error looks like this:

    b'mox3.mox.UnexpectedMethodCallError: Unexpected method call.
    unexpected:- expected:+'
    b"- Client.delete_port('my_portid1') -> None"
    b'? ^'
    b"+ Client.delete_port('my_portid2') -> None"
    b'?

This is due to the mox record with expected the deletion of multiple
ports on an instance in a specific order. This order is not important
though and also not the same in each test case execution. To make it
explicit in the test case, that the order is *not* important, I've
chosen to define that in the mock records with "InAnyOrder()".

Another solution could have been to ensure the order of the port IDs
through the unit tests, but that could be interpreted as a precondition
for the functional code to work correctly, which is a wrong assumption
and therefore not chosen for this fix.

Closes-Bug: 1521599

Change-Id: I6ee4512d221aed48ee56f6cca19744f20f70cbe0
'}]
commit_message:
Fix TestNeutronv2.test_deallocate_for_instance_2* race failures

The unit tests
    test_deallocate_for_instance_2_with_requested
    test_deallocate_for_instance_2
in
    nova.tests.unit.network.test_neutronv2.TestNeutronv2
fail randomly. An example error looks like this:

    b'mox3.mox.UnexpectedMethodCallError: Unexpected method call.
    unexpected:- expected:+'
    b"- Client.delete_port('my_portid1') -> None"
    b'? ^'
    b"+ Client.delete_port('my_portid2') -> None"
    b'?

This is due to the mox record with expected the deletion of multiple
ports on an instance in a specific order. This order is not important
though and also not the same in each test case execution. To make it
explicit in the test case, that the order is *not* important, I've
chosen to define that in the mock records with "InAnyOrder()".

Another solution could have been to ensure the order of the port IDs
through the unit tests, but that could be interpreted as a precondition
for the functional code to work correctly, which is a wrong assumption
and therefore not chosen for this fix.

Closes-Bug: 1521599

Change-Id: I6ee4512d221aed48ee56f6cca19744f20f70cbe0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/71/314671/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.moxed_client.delete_port(port).InAnyOrder("delete_port_group")

commit_message:
Make git_diff in list_changes more generic

The git_diff method is currently only used for listing requirements
changes, and that's actually hard-coded into the method itself
with the header it uses before running the git diff command.

This makes the method more generic and adds a specific method
for dumping requirements changes.

The hope is to build on this by adding code that parses the
requirements diff output looking for new dependencies added
in stable branch release requests so we can fail those types
of backports.

Change-Id: If06b2a154029c78a183774347ab7e787ee50150b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/85/278785/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def git_diff(workdir, repo, git_range, file_pattern, title=None, return_output=False): """Run a git diff on any files that match the pattern in the repo. :param workdir: The base working directory for the repo. :param repo: The git repo to diff. :param git_range: The git diff range argument. :param file_pattern: A file glob pattern for listing files to diff. :param title: A header to print before dumping results (if return_output is False). If not provided, the file_pattern and git_range is used for a generic header. :param return_output: Specify True if you the output from the git diff command should be returned to the caller, else it's dumped to stdout by default. """ # check to see if we should print a header if not return_output: if title: header(title) else: header('%s changes %s' % (file_pattern, git_range)) output = subprocess.check_output(cmd, cwd=repo_dir) if return_output: return output print(output) def dump_reqs_changes(workdir, repo, git_range): """Dumps requirements changes in the given repo within the given range""" git_diff(workdir, repo, git_range, '*requirements*.txt', 'Requirements Changes %s' % git_range) dump_reqs_changes(workdir, project['repo'], git_range)
deleted_lines: def git_diff(workdir, repo, git_range, file_pattern): header('Requirements Changes %s' % git_range) subprocess.check_call(cmd, cwd=repo_dir) print() git_diff(workdir, project['repo'], git_range, '*requirements*.txt')

commit_message:
yum-minimal : better cleanup of initial yum failure

If the initial yum install into the chroot fails, we can leave behind
a lockfile and an incorrectly modified rpmmacros.

Change this so we run the cleanup unconditionally.

Change-Id: Ia9f9c4c845e5f34d33ff9a4ab7226c9175283757
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/77/308077/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: install $@ && rc=$? || rc=$? # We modified the base system - make sure we clean up always! rm $HOME/.rpmmacros.dib.lock if [ $rc != 0 ]; then die "Initial yum install to chroot failed! Can not continue." fi

subject: yum-minimal: strip locale archive
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-12 05:35:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/6dc3e9b2d57e6e562f449cce9ca4e91c225b76be', 'message': "yum-minimal: strip locale archive to en_* locales

Rather than removing a bunch of locale related stuff in cleanup, use a
common method to strip the locale archive down to en_* locales (which
ends up with a locale-archive of about 3.5MiB, which isn't too bad).

Note, as discussed in the bug referenced, might be possible in the
future to only generate these at install-time with some rpm flag
trickery.  Since this is common across Centos & Fedora, we want the
LCD method to keep things simple.

commit_message:
yum-minimal: strip locale archive

Rather than removing all locale related stuff in cleanup, strip the
locale archive and rebuild it.

Building just en_US (along with POSIX/C) brings things inline with
debootstrap.  As discussed in the bug referenced, this is about the
best we can do for Centos7.

Fedora 24 has split languages out into packages so we don't have to do
this, but I have not dealt with that yet.  A guard is put in place so
we make sure we revisit this when we try to build F24.

Change-Id: I3f384d23e52effd6a09f47134746caa4a5c586be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/99/304399/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Stripping all locales is a bad idea. See [1] and there might be # better ways to do this in the future. For now, we take the # suggestion in there for reducing this to a small subset of en_* # locales. [1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=156477 # strip down to en_* locales localedef --delete-from-archive \ $(localedef --list-archive | grep -v -i '^en' | xargs) # prepare template mv /usr/lib/locale/locale-archive /usr/lib/locale/locale-archive.tmpl # rebuild archive /usr/sbin/build-locale-archive # empty template echo > /usr/locale/locale-archive.tmpl

commit_message:
Fix up EPEL element

For whatever reason, RHEL identifies itself with DISTRO "rhel" for 6
and "rhel7" for 7, but centos just uses "centos" and DIB_RELEASE.  So
this was wrong and installing EPEL6 on centos7.

But we can simplify it completely for centos because that comes with
the epel-release package already included.

Change-Id: I2b8f5d30b850fef46b4a5ba32a917abcbf25932c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/13/306213/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [[ ${DISTRO_NAME} =~ "centos" ]]; then # Centos has "epel-release" in extras, which is default enabled. yum install epel-release else # For RHEL, we have to scrape the download page to find the latest # release and install that [ -n "$ARCH" ] if [ 'amd64' = "$ARCH" ] ; then ARCH="x86_64" fi BASE_URL=${DIB_EPEL_MIRROR:-https://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel} case "$DISTRO_NAME" in rhel7) RELEASE=7 URL=$BASE_URL/$RELEASE/x86_64/e/ ;; rhel) RELEASE=6 URL=$BASE_URL/$RELEASE/$ARCH/ ;; *) echo "$DISTRO_NAME is not supported" exit 1 ;; esac PKG_NAME=$(wget -q $URL -O - |grep -oE "(href=\"epel-release-$RELEASE-[0-9,.].*)" | cut -d'"' -f2) rpm -q epel-release || yum install -y $URL/$PKG_NAME
deleted_lines: [ -n "$ARCH" ] if [ 'amd64' = "$ARCH" ] ; then ARCH="x86_64"BASE_URL=${DIB_EPEL_MIRROR:-https://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel} case "$DISTRO_NAME" in rhel7|centos7) RELEASE=7 URL=$BASE_URL/$RELEASE/x86_64/e/ ;; rhel|centos) RELEASE=6 URL=$BASE_URL/$RELEASE/$ARCH/ ;; *) echo "$DISTRO_NAME is not supported" exit 1 ;; esac PKG_NAME=$(wget -q $URL -O - |grep -oE "(href=\"epel-release-$RELEASE-[0-9,.].*)" | cut -d'"' -f2) rpm -q epel-release || yum install -y $URL/$PKG_NAME

commit_message:
DNM: see where instance.pci_devices is getting lazy-loaded

So far we know:

1. build instance
2. start instance
3. backup instance
4. suspend instance
5. resume instance
6. rescue instance
7. unshelve instance

Change-Id: If86b11bf5fe9124c4cbac010ed173c79ccd23eee
Partial-Bug: #1540526

commit_message:
List system dependencies for running common tests

Add an other-requirements.txt file containing a cross-platform list of
dependencies needed for running included tox-based tests. Also include a
tox environment for convenience calling the bindep[*] utility to list
any missing system requirements.

Document bindep and other-requirements usage.

This change is self-testing.

For other-requirements.txt see also
http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/drivers.html#package-requirements

[*] http://docs.openstack.org/infra/bindep/

Change-Id: Iea6f5fecba3b7cb9f6dac7029c0f17fc31fc0e3c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/13/298313/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:bindep] # Do not install any requirements. We want this to be fast and work even if # system dependencies are missing, since it's used to tell you what system # dependencies are missing! This also means that bindep must be installed # separately, outside of the requirements files. deps = bindep commands = bindep

commit_message:
Tighten up ResumingGetter.fast_forward

When the current range is a "last N bytes" request, properly raise
HTTPRequestedRangeNotSatisfiable/RangeAlreadyComplete errors.

Also, add a couple tests for RangeAlreadyComplete with "normal" range
requests.

Change-Id: Icbfd621e7160747c5dfaf9f189da7d74e45a5347
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/61/306661/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if end == 0: # we sent out exactly the first range's worth of bytes, so # we're done with it raise RangeAlreadyComplete() if end is not None and begin == end + 1: # we sent out exactly the first range's worth of bytes, so # we're done with it raise RangeAlreadyComplete() if end is not None and (begin > end or end < 0): req_range.ranges = [(begin, end)] + req_range.ranges[1:]
deleted_lines: if end is not None and begin == end + 1: # we sent out exactly the first range's worth of bytes, so # we're done with it raise RangeAlreadyComplete() elif end and begin > end: else: req_range.ranges = [(begin, end)] + req_range.ranges[1:]

subject: Fix download resumption after getting no data.
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-15 03:08:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/36cb9e1298fdcd24ded3bc7d75a7601b47074b46', 'message': "Fix download resumption after getting no data.

When the proxy is handling an object GET response and an object server
fails to send data in a timely fashion, the proxy can pick up where it
left off with another object server; other than a pause in the
download, the client doesn't even know anything happened.

However, if the proxy received the GET response headers but no data,
it would resume at the wrong spot. In particular, for an N-byte
object, it would ask the second object server for the last N-1 bytes
(or equivalently, all but the first byte). For a replicated storage
policy, this would result in the client getting an abbreviated
download, while for an EC storage policy, the proxy would 500 after
trying to decode a fragment set with a bogus fragment in it.

This commit fixes the resumption logic to ask for all N bytes of the
object from the second object server.

tl;dr: 0 is falsey in Python. Who knew?

Change-Id: Ib9e28c3dceaded1708e7a30844b534566c7a320c
"}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-04-15 23:18:29.000000000', 'files': ['test/unit/proxy/controllers/test_base.py', 'swift/proxy/controllers/base.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/3bc33e59aaeefdb940794782a36517c2b4eb0642', 'message': "Fix download resumption after getting no data.

When the proxy is handling an object GET response and an object server
fails to send data in a timely fashion, the proxy can pick up where it
left off with another object server; other than a pause in the
download, the client doesn't even know anything happened.

However, if the proxy received the GET response headers but no data,
it would resume at the wrong spot. In particular, for an N-byte
object, it would ask the second object server for the last N-1 bytes
(or equivalently, all but the first byte). For a replicated storage
policy, this would result in the client getting an abbreviated
download, while for an EC storage policy, the proxy would 500 after
trying to decode a fragment set with a bogus fragment in it.

This commit fixes the resumption logic to ask for all N bytes of the
object from the second object server.

Change-Id: Ib9e28c3dceaded1708e7a30844b534566c7a320c
"}]
commit_message:
Fix download resumption after getting no data.

When the proxy is handling an object GET response and an object server
fails to send data in a timely fashion, the proxy can pick up where it
left off with another object server; other than a pause in the
download, the client doesn't even know anything happened.

However, if the proxy received the GET response headers but no data,
it would resume at the wrong spot. In particular, for an N-byte
object, it would ask the second object server for the last N-1 bytes
(or equivalently, all but the first byte). For a replicated storage
policy, this would result in the client getting an abbreviated
download, while for an EC storage policy, the proxy would 500 after
trying to decode a fragment set with a bogus fragment in it.

This commit fixes the resumption logic to ask for all N bytes of the
object from the second object server.

Change-Id: Ib9e28c3dceaded1708e7a30844b534566c7a320c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/27/306227/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if end is not None and begin == end + 1: elif end is not None and begin is not None: elif end is not None:
deleted_lines: if end and begin == end + 1: elif end and begin: elif end:

subject: Split YAML & JSON parsing
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-22 01:23:32.000000000', 'files': ['bin/dib-lint'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/8b4a5e9919dfec2dc46d51d5ea6ef56b74171d7e', 'message': 'Split YAML & JSON parsing

It turns out that invalid JSON can be valid YAML ... thus if you mess
up a pkg-map file that still works as a YAML file dib-lint will let it
pass, but when pkg-map later tries to open it as a JSON file, it
fails.

Parse each type separately to catch these problems.

Change-Id: Ib3985e7d1599ed6bf3b7a73b786a53177b71fae0
'}]
commit_message:
Split YAML & JSON parsing

It turns out that invalid JSON can be valid YAML ... thus if you mess
up a pkg-map file that still works as a YAML file dib-lint will let it
pass, but when pkg-map later tries to open it as a JSON file, it
fails.

Parse each type separately to catch these problems.

Change-Id: Ib3985e7d1599ed6bf3b7a73b786a53177b71fae0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/34/309234/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: echo "Checking YAML parsing..." for i in $(find elements -type f -name '*.yaml'); do echo "Parsing $i"except yaml.parser.ParserError: sys.exit(1) " error "$i is not a valid YAML file" fi done echo "Checking pkg-map files..." for i in $(find elements -type f \ -name 'pkg-map' -a \! -executable); do echo "Parsing $i" py_check=" import json import sys try: objs = json.load(open('$i')) except ValueError: sys.exit(1) " if ! python -c "$py_check"; then error "$i is not a valid JSON file"
deleted_lines: echo "Checking YAML & JSON parsing" for i in $(find elements -name '*.yaml' \ -o \( -name pkg-map -type f -a \! -executable \)); doimport json objs = json.load(open('$i')) sys.exit(0) except ValueError: pass try: sys.exit(0) except yaml.parser.ParserError: pass sys.exit(1)" error "$i is not a valid yaml/json file"

commit_message:
Increase min cap of glance_store requirement

The python-swiftclient 3.0.0 release results in glance_store tests
breakage that should be fixed in glance_store 0.13.1 release.
stable/mitaka currently cannot install python-swiftclient 3.0.0 with
glance_store stable/mitaka min requirement of 0.13.0. Increasing the min
required version of glance_store should fix this issue.

Change-Id: If6b24176fc55770db57af08f1246816a5ed0994c
Depends-On: Ib781f140a06a131cbeda7e7bbf91981fd7092c72

commit_message:
Create clustercheck after mysql-server

- Under some circumstances clustercheck user/files are created before
  mysql-server is fully set up. This patch changes the behavior to
  create user after mysql-server
- Create my.cnf primary controller. It only helps to bootstrap the
  cluster. After all we link it to our my.localhost.cnf. We don't need
  to set it up on non primary controllers.

Change-Id: I97de2a01b79851eeca34524c92f406c99ea56cda
Closes-Bug: 1571763
Closes-Bug: 1577462
Signed-off-by: Sergii Golovatiuk <sgolovatiuk@mirantis.com>

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-06 20:06:42.000000000', 'files': ['tools/cruft.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/commit/836a390b910bc2e0945f41d1c9f8a5f39e556ef8', 'message': "Add semi-colon as separator for parsing package names

commit_message:
Add semi-colon as separator for parsing package names

If we don't do this then the following line:
weakrefmethod;python_version=='2.7' or python_version=='2.6' # PSF

ends up as:
weakrefmethod;python_version

in the cruft output. So we need to add ';' to get the output
as 'weakrefmethod'

Change-Id: I7b32bfe70df3bb24ca301db9952d76451674a0db

commit_message:
Use oslo module for messaging (rabbit) configuration

Change-Id: I75dbd9bf37d812a560a401eee2a293cee876a036
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-magnum refs/changes/24/313024/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # [*rpc_backend*] # (optional) The rpc backend implementation to use, can be: # rabbit (for rabbitmq) # Defaults to 'rabbit' # $rpc_backend = 'rabbit', 'DEFAULT/rpc_backend' : value => $rpc_backend; } oslo::messaging::rabbit { 'magnum_config': rabbit_password => $rabbit_password, rabbit_virtual_host => $rabbit_virtual_host, rabbit_host => $rabbit_host, rabbit_port => $rabbit_port, rabbit_hosts => $rabbit_hosts, rabbit_use_ssl => $rabbit_use_ssl, kombu_ssl_version => $kombu_ssl_version, kombu_ssl_keyfile => $kombu_ssl_keyfile, kombu_ssl_certfile => $kombu_ssl_certfile, kombu_ssl_ca_certs => $kombu_ssl_ca_certs, } oslo::messaging::notifications { 'magnum_config': driver => $notification_driver
deleted_lines: 'DEFAULT/rpc_backend' : value => 'rabbit'; 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_password' : value => $rabbit_password, secret => true; 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_virtual_host' : value => $rabbit_virtual_host; 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_use_ssl' : value => $rabbit_use_ssl; 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/kombu_ssl_ca_certs' : value => $kombu_ssl_ca_certs; 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/kombu_ssl_certfile' : value => $kombu_ssl_certfile; 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/kombu_ssl_keyfile' : value => $kombu_ssl_keyfile; 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/kombu_ssl_version' : value => $kombu_ssl_version; } if ! is_service_default($rabbit_hosts) and $rabbit_hosts { magnum_config { 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_hosts': value => join(any2array($rabbit_hosts), ',') } } else { magnum_config { 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_host': value => $rabbit_host } magnum_config { 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_port': value => $rabbit_port } magnum_config { 'oslo_messaging_rabbit/rabbit_hosts': ensure => absent } } if !is_service_default($notification_driver) and $notification_driver { magnum_config { 'DEFAULT/notification_driver': value => join(any2array($notification_driver), ','); } } else { magnum_config { 'DEFAULT/notification_driver': ensure => absent; }
